body: If we move `Option` etc. to a crate without `fail!()` does that mean that methods like `.unwrap` and `.expect` have to be implemented in a different crate via traits?
@huonw Yes.

It's going to get pretty painful when the pointers and containers are defined in a primitive crate, methods for a default allocator are added in another crate and finally more methods requiring failure and other runtime features are added in libstd.

"It's going to get pretty painful" is not at all a reason to not pursue this. This is an awesome effort, and I would love to pursue this further, it's already looking really promising.

I want to think a bit about the name `libprim`, something about it doesn't sit completely right with me.

It's a reason to consider another way of doing it. Spreading out the implementation of each container between 3 or more crates is complex, and will require changes to the user-facing API due to the additional traits.

Some thoughts
- I think the entire `iter` module could be in this crate
- Why can't Clone/cmp methods be added? They don't inherently have any allocations, although some implementations might. (same with operators)

> - Why can't Clone/cmp methods be added? They don't inherently have any allocations, although some implementations might. (same with operators)

Types like `~` need to have the trait implemented in the crate that defines `Clone` atm.

> Spreading out the implementation of each container between 3 or more crates is complex, and will require changes to the user-facing API due to the additional traits

You're talking about a hypothetical thing which hasn't happened yet. Everything here is just a consolidation which should happen anyway, and this is no more difficult to understand than it was before. 

I agree we should tread lightly when adding things like one-off traits. If you have concrete suggestions about how to explore this use case, we always welcome them, but unconstructive criticism is not particularly helpful
I'm really liking this, awesome work!

> Everything here is just a consolidation which should happen anyway, and this is no more difficult to understand than it was before.

In what way is it a consolidation?

> You're talking about a hypothetical thing which hasn't happened yet.

It's not hypothetical. A language feature was even added with allocators as the primary use case. A good API for them has already been worked out and tested.

With this design, the containers will end up being defined in this primitive crate, with a default allocator crate providing extension methods like `new` and `with_capacity`. The standard library will then provide further extensions where failure or other runtime features are required.

For containers not in the standard library, the crate solution requires splitting them into 3 crates. Third party crates are also unable to reduce the pain to solely a documentation issue by exporting everything in a prelude.

> I agree we should tread lightly when adding things like one-off traits. If you have concrete suggestions about how to explore this use case, we always welcome them, but unconstructive criticism is not particularly helpful.

My concrete suggestion to is to use compile-time selection rather than exposing many implementation details as traits and making heavy usage of dynamic dispatch. I've already explored different ways of doing this and settled on configuration flags as by far the least bad solution without explicit compiler support.

> I've already explored different ways of doing this and settled on configuration flags as by far the least bad solution without explicit compiler support

This is not very convincing, what data do you have to support this?

I explained the problem for containers above. This same issue reoccurs for any module that's not entirely freestanding. The `Vec<T>` type would be defined here, with `new` and `with_capacity` in the default allocator crate, and then the failing slice methods need to be split between an abort crate and the standard library. If unwinding is deemed an optional feature not requiring the rest of the runtime, then an unwinding crate is necessary as an alternative to the `abort` crate. Since the slice methods need to be split into at least two groups, you end up with two traits instead of one.

For another example, traits like `Reader` and `Writer` should be defined in this crate, as the traits themselves do not require runtime support. This means `impl Reader for ~Reader` needs to be removed along with further ripple effects.

An alternative that I'm even less fond of is using weak symbols or dynamically selected functionality for everything from unwinding vs. failure to the choice of default allocator. It's not pay-for-what-you-use and will necessitate the need for an alternative library without the overhead.

Regardless, discussion of containers and such are irrelevant to this PR because it doesn't deal with them at all. I think we'll cross that bridge when we get there.

Thinking about it, why can't the comparisons trait move to this crate? I would expect that `impl<T: Eq> Eq for ~T` would be ok because you're never _creating_ a `~T` value, you're just using one. As in, I think @huonw is right for why `Clone` can't be in this crate (it requires an allocation to clone `~T`, but things that just operate on `~T` (comparisons) seems like they should be in this crate.

> Regardless, discussion of containers and such are irrelevant to this PR because it doesn't deal with them at all. I think we'll cross that bridge when we get there.

It's completely relevant to this pull request. I explained the problems that are going to be caused by choosing to do the split like this, and doing it in incremental steps doesn't avoid them. It's worth discussing the design constraints and existing experiments to determine the best way to do it.

> Thinking about it, why can't the comparisons trait move to this crate? I would expect that `impl<T: Eq> Eq for ~T` would be ok because you're never _creating_ a `~T` value, you're just using one. As in, I think @huonw is right for why `Clone` can't be in this crate (it requires an allocation to clone `~T`, but things that just operate on `~T` (comparisons) seems like they should be in this crate.

It works, and all of the pointer-like and container-like types defined in modules like `std::rc`, `std::hashmap` and `std::trie` can be almost entirely moved here too.

The `Arc` and `MutexArc` types seem to be moving to a `libsync` crate, so that will be split into `libsync_prim`, `libsync_heap` and `libsync`.

> It's completely relevant to this pull request.

Do you have any problems with the specific components moved in this pull request? Do you disagree that the functions moved can be used in all contexts? I am 100% behind every change made in this pull request. I never said I was 100% behind all future movements

> The Arc and MutexArc types seem to be moving to a libsync crate, so that will be split into libsync_prim, libsync_heap and libsync.

I do not believe that this is the correct way to do this. I also do not believe that it should block this. As implemented, `libprim` is usable _everywhere_, and I want that. I wouldn't be surprised if `libprim` isn't very featureful. I don't believe that the goal of `libprim` is to be featureful, but rather it's supposed to eliminate any boilerplate you need to get running with rust (hiding language implementation details).

If you have concerns about _this pull request_ in specific, please voice them. If you believe that future movement will cause problems, then please suggest constructive comments for how to improve _this pull request_. If the comments have nothing to do with _this pull request_, then please save them for later.

I share your concerns in having an explosion of libraries, and I not believe that it is the right way to approach this. Again though, _this pull request_ is something I believe needs to happen.

> Do you have any problems with the specific components moved in this pull request?

Yes, as explained above, I don't think this is the right solution. Moving them from the standard library is enacting a specific solution without having considered the alternatives.

> Do you disagree that the functions moved can be used in all contexts?

This isn't part of what I'm discussing. I'm not doing a review of whether or not the code will compile, but whether is it the right design.

> I am 100% behind every change made in this pull request. I never said I was 100% behind all future movements

If there is not a willingness to move all of the useful functionality not depending on the runtime to the crate, then it is a step backwards as it is far inferior to the existing solution.

> If you have concerns about this pull request in specific, please voice them. If you believe that future movement will cause problems, then please suggest constructive comments for how to improve this pull request. If the comments have nothing to do with this pull request, then please save them for later.

I think moving this functionality will cause problems. It will create a separate freestanding standard library without most of the usable functionality it should have. I think it will be unlikely that the rest of the usable functionality will be moved due to the sacrifices involved (as covered in my previous comments).

> but rather it's supposed to eliminate any boilerplate you need to get running with rust (hiding language implementation details).

It doesn't do this, as it exposes the intrinsics in a module named _intrinsics_ rather than exposing functionality in modules based on the functionality involved. Many of these are also `unsafe` despite being completely safe, due the implementation detail of being an intrinsic. I'm all for hiding the language implementation details, but I don't really see what splitting the standard library has to do with it. The existing freestanding Rust library doesn't expose intrinsics in the public API.

I think it's important to do this in a way where it can be made transparent to the user-level API documentation in the future. I don't think this split will allow for doing that due to the trait coherence rules.

@thestinger I don't understand how your arguments apply to this patch; they seem to be about future patches. I have made very few changes to the types here. This is mostly just moving modules around and thinking harder about their interdependencies than we we have in the past with everything entangled in std. std still has nearly the exact same interface, and where it doesn't it is in my opinion for the better.

I am trying to figure out how to make Rust's libraries maximally useful in any environment, and doing so by extracting the parts of std that can work everywhere.
@alexcrichton Agree the name `prim` is not good.
@brson Perhaps we can resurrect the name `core`?
@kballard To avoid confusion, I think no, it should not be named 'core'.

@alexcrichton `Clone` can't be included without making `prim` depend on having a global allocator, because the implementations for the vector types need to be defined next to the trait. I do think having everything that doesn't need runtime dependencies in one place has its own benefits, both practical and aesthetic, but I don't want to sacrifice the overall design of the standard library.

I would like to have some kind of _lazy_ language item so that a crate like prim could include code that depends on the malloc and free lang items while not requiring them to be defined in the local crate. There is probably a lot of code that just needs to declare that it needs the global heap, but has no other runtime needs. If we can push most of std into the crate that only needs unique allocation then we have a highly-compatible library.
The main runtime features that the library needs are allocation, failure, and possibly local data.
@thestinger What other strategies might we take to reduce the standard library's platform-dependencies?

Two possible naming suggestions:
- libkrust (this is the kernel of all functionality for rust crates)
- librust (this crate is what it means to be rust)

Is there not a solution whereby we use weak symbols/default lang items but statically link to avoid overhead? So `libstd` would not include `libprim` as a dynamically loaded dependency but would instead statically link to it. In turn `libprim` would leave things like the `~` allocator undefined.

I'm not a fan of either crate explosion, interface explosion, or `#[cfg()]` explosion.
`core` sounds good; I think it should be considered again.

@pcwalton: The metadata could be taught to mark code as falling under certain profile flags, and then cordon off code based on the profile of the application. Link-time optimization would strip away the dead parts. I think this would be the best way to do it. Without the compiler feature, configuration flags could be used but recompilation would be required.

The failure vs. abort issue could be tackled via weak symbols (`libunwind` and `libabort`).

> Regardless, discussion of containers and such are irrelevant to this PR because it doesn't deal with them at all. I think we'll cross that bridge when we get there.

@alexcrichton , this may very well not be the place to discuss such matters, but then where is? Instead of shutting down the discussion, please give us a link to the place where it has been previously discussed so that the discussion may continue. And if all prior discussion has only happened behind closed doors, then you shouldn't be surprised that people may be feeling blindsided by its sudden appearance.

Importantly, it would be nice to have a document that establishes the scope of libprim. Freedom from dependencies is lovely, but if it only ever intends to provide 1% of what rust-core provides today, or if upfront design decisions _prevent_ it from ever providing more than that 1%, then it surely won't suffice in avoiding the sort of fragmentation that we all hope to avoid and all this work will have been for naught anyway.

I'm also concerned at the latent hostility that I'm sensing towards @thestinger . And not just here in this thread, and not just from a single person. Though he's been combative in the past, Daniel has remained remarkably level-headed here despite having his opinion persistently dismissed at every opportunity.

Let us also not overlook the fact that Daniel has, as far as I can tell, more experience designing dependency-free Rust library APIs than anyone else. A willingness to learn from his experience will save us time and hardship.

I'm not commenting on the PR itself nor am I saying it's the wrong approach. I'm merely asking for more openness from the developers in heeding the concerns of informed and knowledgeable community members.

> Instead of shutting down the discussion, please give us a link to the place where it has been previously discussed so that the discussion may continue

I apologize if my comments came across like this, I most certainly did not want to shut down _all_ discussion. This PR has not been internally discussed, so I have no links to give you for a previous discussion. I'm sorry that I overreacted.

> this may very well not be the place to discuss such matters, but then where is?

We have a very large number of discussion forums including the issue tracker, the mailing list, IRC, and reddit. I felt as if the discussion was diverging from this particular PR and beginning to discuss hypothetical future changes, but I may have been wrong.

> Importantly, it would be nice to have a document that establishes the scope of libprim

I agree, and I think that we should approach this PR carefully before taking action on it.

> I'm merely asking for more openness from the developers in heeding the concerns of informed and knowledgeable community members.

I am very sorry and I very much apologize if I appeared like this, it is the opposite of what I would like to be doing.

> I am very sorry and I very much apologize if I appeared like this, it is the opposite of what I would like to be doing.

It was not my intention to single you out. I merely wish to voice concern regarding a broader trend that I perceive wherein Daniel's criticisms are peremptorily dismissed. I'm unsure whether this is due to his past history of confrontational language (an area in which he has greatly improved recently, much to my relief) or whether it is due to a more general allergy to criticism amongst the devs. In my opinion, his willingness to vocally point out potential design flaws (multiplied by his deep familiarity with Rust's design and implementation) makes him one of the most valuable members of the Rust community. He's a knowledgeable programmer and a hard worker. We would be much diminished without him. And yet sometimes I get the (hopefully mistaken!) impression that he's been blackballed by the developers. The fact that he's so long endured this dismissive attitude is a testament to his commitment, though I wonder for how much longer he can keep it up.

> I most certainly did not want to shut down all discussion. This PR has not been internally discussed, so I have no links to give you for a previous discussion.

For the record, I'm personally fine with allowing the developers to land whatever they want with minimal discussion (though I don't pretend to speak for everyone). We're pre-1.0, after all, and this is pretty much how we've always operated. "Move fast and break things." Just beware that going it alone risks missing out on input from people who have already explored this design space, and could waste us time in the long run. Be cautious as well to ensure that such an attitude is not misinterpreted as disdain for anyone not employed at Mozilla Research.

@thestinger I'm not sure exactly what you mean but I think this is roughly what I was suggesting, yes. In other words, you LTO the revamped `libprim` with `libstd` if you're developing a full-featured userspace app, or with your kernel, embedded app, or minimalist application if you're developing one of those.
What do people think of "tiny" or "mini" for this library? Go had a freestanding implementation called "tiny" for a while until it was removed.
I have added this to the meeting agenda.

@bstrie I've read through @thestinger's posts on this thread multiple times. What I believe he is saying that taking this design too far risks creation of too many traits, and he does not want to do that. I acknowledge this concern, but note that the organization of modules in this pull request does not suffer from that problem. I've asked him for his recommendations on what we should do instead in order to go from a monolithic library to one that has isolated platform dependencies.

@bstrie It concerns me that you are unsatisfied, and I want to hear your thoughts on governance of the Rust project, but I'd rather not discuss interpersonal issues on the bug tracker.

> @kballard To avoid confusion, I think no, it should not be named 'core'.

@brson What confusion do you foresee?
@bjz Naming it 'core' would obscure its relationship with @thestinger's rust-core library.

The alternative I was thinking about before stumbling on this discussion was having a build of libstd with `--cfg no_rt`. And without knowing if it was possible, having crates with a `#[no_rt]` tag magically being linked against the simplified libstd instead.

I don't know if this falls under the cfg explosion heading though.

Edit: Might be off topic for this pull, but I was also thinking a `#[no_libc]` tag to link against a totally freestanding libstd.

@bharrisau `#[no_rt]', '#[no_libc]', and '#[no_std]' seem like great options.

I wonder if the Rust community will be able to tolerate the refactoring of the stdlib that will be required if we want to make Rust truly freestanding like C++. Inevitably, the stdlib would require more traits/complexity in order to gain generality. But I think it would be worth it to have a truly universal standard library for Rust.

I don't think it's inevitable that extra traits or complexity are required. Zero additional traits are required if this is done as a compile-time configuration switch instead of splitting into crates. The documentation will also remain the same, but the HTML viewer could be enhanced to allow setting configuration flags.
@thestinger is there any functionality that could be extracted that currently relies on the runtime?
@thestinger what do you mean by 'For containers not in the standard library, the crate solution requires splitting them into 3 crates'?

@brson: Containers need to be available for freestanding usage. However, there are convenience methods depending on a default allocator being present, and then further convenience methods depending on runtime features like the task-local random number generator for seeding a hash table.

For a third party library, the crate split solution requires supplying 3 crates to support the three profiles. This is also true of the containers defined in this repository unless they are all included in the base libraries (libstd, ...).

I'm still not quite following where these three crates are coming from, can you concretely elaborate about these use cases? Some specific questions I have:
- What are these convenience methods?
- Where do allocators come into this? 
- Why three crates?
- How does this affect things like creation of hash tables? You can't retroactively add static methods, so you'd be limited to Trait::new_seeded() which is not quite as elegant as HashMap::new()

I'm still not understanding a few things.
- I would expect that _all_ environments can assume an allocator exists, so I don't follow why `new` is a convenience method. 
- I still don't understand where this number 3 is coming from
- I would imagine that a truly generic container needs to handle allocation failure, and it doesn't appear that these methods you're talking about are designed to handle this.

> - I would expect that _all_ environments can assume an allocator exists, so I don't follow why `new` is a convenience method.

The `new` function is a convenience method because it assumes you want to be using a single global dynamic allocator instance across the entire program. To support allocators, there's a need for a method taking the allocator instance as a parameter and `new` becomes a wrapper around this function passing the _default_ allocator instance.

There are certainly environments without dynamic memory allocation and global variables so I don't think the `new` function can be provided in a crate supporting the freestanding use case. It _can_ be provided without the rest of the runtime, so that's a second crate.

The difference between abort and unwinding is easier to deal with and I think it could just be dealt with at a compiler level.

> I would imagine that a truly generic container needs to handle allocation failure, and it doesn't appear that these methods you're talking about are designed to handle this.

I haven't given any examples of methods unable to handle allocation failure. Handling the allocation error case for vectors and hash tables means returning an `Option` from functions like `push` and from those doing eager allocation like `with_capacity`. The `new`/`with_alloc` function doesn't need to allocate any memory for a vector or hash table (see `std::vec_ng`) but `new` requires a default global allocator.

With a configuration-based solution, features like floating point can be made optional without re-organization of the library. Splitting out a floating point crate would work but is a backwards incompatible change and may even require new traits. In the future, more features will become usable in the freestanding use case (containers) but other features (like floating point, and mutable global state) will also become optional to support more platforms. I don't think the crate splitting solution is a scalable one.
@thestinger In other words, this issue will have to be resolved before 1.0?

I don't think it would be a meaningful 1.0 release if it didn't offer basic sequence, map and set containers with a reasonable subset of the methods marked as stable.

All I'm trying to push for here is being able to use the standard library while producing binaries in the same size and performance class as C and with a similar set of runtime dependencies. A feature bringing significant size/performance overhead or new runtime dependencies should be something you can opt-out from (like `-fno-exceptions`, `-fno-rtti`, `-fno-cxa-atexit`, etc.) without losing unrelated parts of the standard library.

This is not just relevant to the freestanding use cases but is also necessary to make the language an appealing alternative to C for building the libraries behind every major application. It should be possible to write libraries in Rust for use in existing and future projects in _many_ different languages without a significant overhead in code size and dependencies over C and without having to opt-out of the standard library.

At the very least, all of this work will help to structure libstd so it is
more manageable into the future.
On 05/02/2014 7:19 am, "Daniel Micay" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I don't think it would be a meaningful 1.0 release if it didn't offer
> basic sequence, map and set containers with a reasonable subset of the
> methods marked as stable.
> 
> All I'm trying to push for here is being able to use the standard library
> while producing binaries in the same size and performance class as C and
> with a similar set of runtime dependencies. A feature bringing significant
> size/performance overhead or new runtime dependencies should be something
> you can opt-out from (like -fno-exceptions, -fno-rtti, -fno-cxa-atexit,
> etc.) without losing unrelated parts of the standard library.
> 
> This is not just relevant to the freestanding use cases but is also
> necessary to make the language an appealing alternative to C for building
> the libraries behind every major application. It should be possible to
> write libraries in Rust for use in existing and future projects in _many_different languages without a significant overhead in code size and
> dependencies over C and without having to opt-out of the standard library.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/mozilla/rust/pull/11968#issuecomment-34119999
> .

In what way does it make the situation better? What is the advantage to having some functionality arbitrarily split into an underlying library? It's only going to be used through the regular standard library because it's not a viable standalone library and _won't be_ for the reasons I've stated above.

I meant structuring libstd so it can be built with less dependencies.
On 05/02/2014 8:01 am, "Daniel Micay" notifications@github.com wrote:

> In what way does it make the situation better? What is the advantage to
> having some functionality arbitrarily split into an underlying library?
> It's only going to be used through the regular standard library because
> it's not a viable standalone library and _won't be_ for the reasons I've
> stated above.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/mozilla/rust/pull/11968#issuecomment-34123283
> .

It will have the same dependencies before and after these changes. I think it's a clear step _away_ from exposing as many features as possible based on the runtime environment. There will be the runtime-dependent standard library pulling in megabytes of Rust code for the smallest utilities/libraries and the crippled freestanding library without even a vector type. We can do so much better...

An example of the contortions this would cause: we won't be able to have methods for both `*T -> Option<&T>` and `Option<T> -> T` (unwrap) without using extra traits, since we'd have to define `Option<T>` in libprim in the first case, but libprim doesn't have failure, so `unwrap` would need to be defined in a different crate... which requires a trait.

(And similarly, if `Option` was defined in a crate with failure, we'd need a trait to add the method to `*T`; though a solution for either case would be to just write it as a free-standing function rather than a method.)

I think this split will directly have other negative effects on the API, due to requirements like that.

The unwinding vs. abort issue would be easy to solve with a weak symbol. At the same time, unwinding is problematic because you get far faster compile times and significantly smaller binaries when unwinding isn't supported. It also enables more LLVM transformations, as a function that's not `nounwind` is not a pure function it can optimize out or move around.

Where would this leave libraries that want to work in multiple environments? For example, `zlib` has a [port](https://github.com/charsyam/linux-kernel-3.8/blob/master/lib/zlib_deflate/deflate.c) in the Linux kernel, has a standard C API with file I/O, and an idiomatic Rust API would be nice too. Could I write my own `#[cfg]` magic to keep a single `lib.rs` and compile as appropriate? 

If yes, Rust should provide the appropriate options for interoperability with other such libraries and end user convenience, at which point I don't see why `libstd` wouldn't make use of them. We can refactor it without splitting into multiple crates. (I'd name it something like`#[profile(freestanding, no_libc, no_runtime, idiomatic/full_runtime]`, but that's a different issue.)

If not, and I would have to split into separate completely different crates, that would go against pretty much everything Rust has done so far with `#[crate_type]` and all the `#[cfg]` stuff. Building multiple `libstd`s is nowhere near as bad as the mess this would make in Rust libraries, especially with `rustpkg` dead and buried.

@huonw @thestinger I believe I now understand the scenario where new traits arise, e.g. huonw's [example](#issuecomment-34124425) where one needs to put `Option`'s `unwrap` method into a separate trait in a different crate, since `libprim` does not have `fail`

(I'm still wrapping my head around the multiple crate issue, which AFAICT arises when a library developer wants to allow their library to be used in many target contexts; a library developer who is content to target a narrow audience, e.g. non-kernel developers, may be able to get away with only one crate.  I think.)

Anyway, I want to understand the basis for objecting to splitting a method like `unwrap` off into a separate trait.  Here are the main objections I have been able to imagine (though perhaps some are invalid; feel free to point that out if so):
- The documentation generated when a set of methods is split amongst separate traits is non-ideal.
- Without glob imports, it is a pain to import the individual traits into client code using the methods.
- It is more boilerplate to write each `impl` for each of the traits on a particular type that one is introducing; one would prefer to write a small number of `impls` (preferably _one_ impl) with all of the methods of interest listed underneath that single `impl`.

Does forcing the introduction of new traits have more problems that I have missed, or is the above cover the cases reasonably well?

(Again, at this point I'm just trying to understand the problems introduced by the split-into-many-traits phenomenon alone; I can imagine there are further problems introduced when library developers are forced to generate several crates to ensure their library is usable in a maximal set of contexts.)

I think that if we do go down this path, it definitely puts pressure on us to support glob imports properly, rather than potentially deprecating them.  The other two objections above I have less of an opinion on; my gut tells me that they seem surmountable, e.g. via better tooling for the first and some macro or some new `impl` extension for the second.
FWIW, I had no idea what "prim" means before reading #11828. Is "libprimitive" too long?

@pnkfelix: Part of my complaint is that moving functionality to the freestanding crate is a backwards compatibility risk because it introduces new traits to add extensions methods. The other part is that we may decide to make functionality _included in the freestanding_ crate like floating point intrinsics optional and it will end up not being present in that crate at all.

I also strongly dislike having the public API include traits that are not carefully thought out functionality aimed at writing generic code. I'm come to view using traits to add extension methods as an anti-pattern because it over-complicates the API and makes me wonder when free functions are actually meant to be used.
(Haskell has only a few typeclasses in its standard lib (and they're almost all very generic), for comparison.)

@huonw: Good example! Haskell has [`Data.String`](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/base-4.6.0.1/docs/Data-String.html) in the [standard](http://www.haskell.org/onlinereport/haskell2010/haskellch16.html#x24-20900016), which has been almost completely abandoned by the community in favor of the external [`text`](https://hackage.haskell.org/package/text),  except for the mandatory usage in core packages like [`process`](http://hackage.haskell.org/package/process-1.2.0.0/docs/System-Process.html#g:2).

My 2 cents would be:
libprim should contain basic primitives such as Option and Clone, which may allocate memory or fail, as exchange_malloc or fail_ cannot be defined there, function lang items would somehow need to be changed so that they're simply referenced as external symbols if not defined within the current crate (for libraries)
Another library called librt should implement lang items such as exchange_malloc, fail_, exception handling, etc

@Tobba: So how do we define the methods on `Option` requiring failure? How do we define the container constructors requiring memory allocation and a task-local random number generator? The API and documentation is going to suffer if the library is split up.

Rust's standard library already rivals most other languages in terms of complexity and code size, while providing a fraction of the features. I think it's clear that increasing the complexity any more is unacceptable, especially when there are other ways to support other profiles.
All of the containers will need to be defined in this libprim library. Where should the `HashMap` constructors without key parameters be implemented?

@thestinger 
I dont see why all containers would need to be implemented in libprim either, those all belong in std, prim should be the basic features such as intrinsics (and all the wrappers you need around them), basics like Option, Result, basic string and slice operations and possibly Rc, though the line would end up being pretty flimsy

If there's no sensible distinction between the libraries, then there's no reason to do the split. Containers do need to be available without a runtime burden, so the standard library would need to work for freestanding usage anyway if they were defined in it.

Trying to get my head around all of the above:

So splitting into crates based on platform/runtim isn't going to work because an impl can't be extended (optional functions must be added as new traits, and nobody wants a trait explosion). Would it be a potential solution if there was a way to extend an impl when re-exporting the object in std? i.e. prim::Option is a subset of std::Option (both are enums, but the std one has more methods in the impl).

I've had a look at using #[cfg] to do freestanding libstd, one of the big annoyances is that the 'deriving' shortcut doesn't play nice with the cfg annotation (the deriving stuff is where lots of the dependency tangling happens). It would be good if things like derive[Clone] could be made dependent on a cfg. It also looks like the #[cfg] is done at compile time - given how rust code is handled in rlibs now it would be good to have a more powerful (lazy?) annotation that isn't evaluated till generating object code.

At least everyone is agreed that it would be nice to have libstd freestanding.

Closing due to inactivity.

I think that something along these lines need to happen, especially for embedded rust usage (in other languages), sometimes pulling in all of `libstd` doesn't quite cut it. There were many different ideas thrown about in this discussion, and a further change such as this may warrant an RFC beforehand to centralize discussion.
